glossdef.para: A cavity of liquefactive necrosis within solid tissue as a result of a localized infection; this can be the result of an acute or a chronic process.
A host that harbors a parasite but is not the normal host for that parasite species.
Pertaining to a group of organisms that resist decolorization by acid-alcohol; typically associated with Mycobacterium and Nocardia spp.
Pathological condition in which the arterial pH drops below the normal value.
The initial phase or most severe phase of a disease.
A specimen that is collected from the patient during the initial or acute illness.
An enlargement of a lymph node or lymph nodes in response to some stimulus such as inflammation or infection; can occur singly or in multiple nodes; also referred to as lymphadenopathy.
Proteins in the bacterial cell surface or cellular appendages that allow bacteria to adhere to a surface or to other cells.
An appendage to an organ or structure.
Caused by one of the HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) retroviruses; the condition is characterized by the depletion of lymphocytes with subsequent failure of the immune system (see AIDS).
Pertaining to a microorganism that must grow in the presence of oxygen (a “strict aerobe”) or may grow in the presence of oxygen (a “facultative aerobe”).
A collection of solid or liquid particles suspended in a gas, such as a liquid that is dispersed in fine droplets through the air.
Relating to the absence of fever.

The interaction between a particulate antigen and antibodies specific for that particular antigen; the antigen-antibody complex leads to the aggregation or clumping of the antigen-containing material.
Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (see advanced HIV disease).
Protective measures to prevent the transmission of airborne disease (such as tuberculosis), such as requiring a respirator mask for providers and a negative-pressure room for patients.
One of a series of two or more different genes that occupy the same location on a homologous chromosome.
Not genetically identical.
Tissue transplanted from a non-genetically identical donor.
Hair loss.

Pertaining to a reaction seen typically on agar medium containing sheep red blood cells, in which the area surrounding a colony has a green hue; the most medically important alpha-hemolytic organism is Streptococcus pneumoniae.
Macrophages that are found in the alveolus of the lung; part of the innate immune system.
An air sac in the lung consisting of a single layer of cells surrounded by a network of capillaries also consisting of a single cell layer; gas exchange occurs here.
A stage of the life cycle for protozoan species within the genus Leishmania; the nonflagellated amastigotes survive within macrophages of the host.
A nodular inflammatory lesion, usually in the wall of the colon, that may develop in chronic amebiasis.
Pertaining to a microorganism that must grow in the absence of oxygen (a “strict anaerobe”) or may grow in the absence of oxygen (a “facultative anaerobe”).
Medications used to decrease pain, such as ibuprofen, morphine, and acetaminophen.
A surgical connection between two hollow structures.
A condition in which the number of functional red blood cells is decreased; this is often associated with symptoms such as pallor, fatigue, shortness of breath, and lethargy.

A lack of the ability of the immune system to respond with a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction to commonly and previously encountered antigens such as mumps and Candida; often seen in patients with advanced HIV disease.
Characteristic of an infection or neoplasm that grows into the surrounding vasculature.
Without jaundice.
A circular rash.
Decreased appetite.
Enlarged lymph nodes in the front of the neck.
Medications that kill bacteria or inhibit bacterial growth.
A substance that is capable of triggering an immune response.
The gradual change in a microorganism's genetic composition after successive generations of reproduction.

A drastic change in a microorganism's genetic composition within one reproductive cycle; typically associated with influenza A viruses in which a new strain is unrecognizable to a previously immune host.

A sudden or gradual change in the expression of an antigen by a microbe; the variation may result in a drastic change in the pathogenicity of the organism or in the host's ability to mount an immune response; antigenic shift and antigenic drift are types of antigenic variation.
Medications that kill the malaria parasite or inhibit its growth.
The degree to which a bacterium can be killed or inhibited by a particular antimicrobial.
Inhibiting the ability of the phagocyte to ingest bacteria, foreign materials, or other cellular debris.
Fever-reducing agents such as aspirin, acetaminophen, and ibuprofen.
Drugs that inhibit HIV.
The structure that opens during systole as blood is ejected from the left ventricle into the aorta and closes during diastole as the left ventricular pressure decreases.
Near the apex of a structure.

Decrease in the numbers of all elements in the blood due to the death of their precursor cells in the bone marrow, where the cells usually mature; often associated with specific chemicals or drugs that are toxic to these cells.
Absence of normal respirations.
Programmed cell death.
Inflammation of the vermiform appendix of the cecum.
Severe joint pain, usually characterized as noninflammatory.
Inflammation or infection of a joint, leading to decreased and painful mobility of the affected joint.
An asexual spore that is budded from the body of some species of fungi.
Disease caused by intestinal nematodes of the genus Ascaris, usually the giant roundworm species Ascaris lumbricoides.
Atypical squamous cells of unknown significance; an intermediate finding on cervical cytology.
Describes fungi that do not have septa dividing their hyphae.
Low number of white cells in cerebrospinal fluid, predominantly lymphocytes; most frequently caused by infection by viruses or fungi.
Removal of fluid by suction.

Absence of the spleen, either congenitally (at birth) or later, often seen in persons with long-standing sickling disease. This condition makes the individual susceptible to infections by certain bacteria and parasites.

An involuntary jerking motion that occurs with various toxic or metabolic encephalopathies, including hepatitic encephalopathy and uremia; most easily demonstrated when the patient is asked to extend his or her arms with the hands pointed up and the fingers extended.
Without outward clinical manifestations of disease.
The inability to coordinate muscle activity during voluntary movements of the head, limbs, or trunk; often associated with cerebellar dysfunction.
The stiffening and narrowing of arteries caused by deposition of cholesterol and associated inflammation.
A process characterized by wasting of specific tissues, organs, or the entire body that can result from a variety of causes.
Decreased virulence of a pathogen through either natural or experimental means.
White blood cells with an abnormal reactive appearance in response to an antigen.
A stain that fluoresces under a UV microscope; used for visualizing acid-fast organisms.

A method based on sounds or sound changes, used during a physical examination to gather data on internal organs such as the heart, lungs, and liver; the most common method involves the use of a stethoscope.
Antibodies produced by the immune system that attack the individual's own proteins in specific cells, tissues, or organs.
Refers to a process that originated in the place where it is found.
Describes a disease caused by an abnormal activation or modulation of the body's immune system toward its own tissues.
Process whereby the host is reinfected by the same organism after the organism has undergone a replication cycle.
Describes a genetic disease, carried on somatic chromosomes, which requires two affected alleles to manifest as disease.
Describes a microorganism with limited pathogenic potential.
Armpit; the area between the upper arm and chest wall where the two join.
The presence of viable bacteria in the bloodstream; may be a transient phenomenon associated with dental care or may be due to a bacterial infection in which bacteria have entered the bloodstream.
The presence of bacteria in the urine.
Polysaccharides of glucose linked by beta-glycosidic bonds, found in most fungal cell walls.
Characteristic seen on blood-containing medium, where bacteria cause complete hemolysis of red blood cells.
An enzyme that can degrade beta-lactam, the active component of penicillin.
Pertaining to the bases of both lungs.
Pertaining to both sides of a symmetrically shaped tissue, organ, or the entire body; for example, the right and left lungs are bilateral organs.
System of ducts through which bile is transported.
Organisms that adhere to each other on a surface, often in a protein matrix.
A procedure that involves the removal of specific tissues from patients for the purpose of diagnosis.
Intentional release or spread of biologic agents, including bacteria, viruses, and toxins.
A temporary lightening of the skin or mucous membranes after direct pressure is applied.
Abnormal contraction of the eyelid.
A pathogen that is spread by contact with blood.
A diagnostic technique that obtains a biopsy of bone marrow along with an aspirate of marrow, generally from the iliac crest.
Describes a mixture of freshwater and salt water.
Irreversible abnormal dilation of the bronchial tree.
Inflammation of the bronchioles (conducting airways of less than 1 mm).
Inflammation or infection of the airways.

The instillation of saline into the airways of the lungs so that samples can be removed and the washings (fluids) can be analyzed for malignancy, inflammation, or infection; also done during bronchoscopy.
The use of a flexible hollow tube to look directly at the trachea, bronchi, and larger airways in the lungs; it is also possible to obtain samples (biopsies, fluids, brushings) through this device.
Episodic constriction of smooth muscles lining the bronchi in response to some kind of irritant or stimulus.
A sign of meningeal irritation, elicited when flexion of the neck causes involuntary flexion of the hips.
A form of asexual reproduction in fungi.
Fluid-filled blister at the junction of the dermis and epidermis, larger in size than a vesicle.
General weight loss or wasting due to a disease process or emotional imbalance.
Focal area of increased deposition of calcium compounds.
A fluorescent stain that binds to chitin, a component of the fungal cell wall.
Bloodstream infection with Candida species.

A polysaccharide (except for Bacillus anthracis, in which it is poly-D-glutamic acid) covering of certain bacteria and yeasts that makes them resistant to phagocytosis by white blood cells; often utilized in vaccines as the antigen.
Beta-lactamase with the ability to hydrolyze penicillin, cephalosporin, and carbapenem antibiotics.
Malignancy of epithelial tissue.
Cessation of normal blood flow due to the inability of the heart to contract.
A collection of immune cells with a “cheese-like” necrotic core, characteristic of certain infectious and autoimmune diseases.
Enzyme that catalyzes the production of water and oxygen from hydrogen peroxide.
Describing inflammation of the mucous membranes in the nose and throat.

A thin tube introduced to a body cavity or blood vessel. Permanent and removable intravascular catheters can be placed in peripheral or central vessels for delivery of fluid, medication, or nutrition and for the removal of wastes through hemodialysis, as well as monitoring of hemodynamic status. Urinary catheters can be introduced through the urethra or through the skin overlying the bladder for drainage of urine. Ventriculoperitoneal catheters can be placed in the ventricles of the brain to drain into the peritoneal cavity for removal of excess fluid in hydrocephalus.
Describing destruction of normal lung tissue and replacement with a cavity, caused by particular organisms or disease processes.

Subset of T lymphocytes that are characterized by the presence of CD4 receptors on their cell membrane surfaces; they assist in turning on the immune response by activating other T and B lymphocytes; also called T-helper cells. Less than 200 cells per μl is seen in adults with advanced HIV disease.
DNA synthesized from a messenger RNA (mRNA) template.
An immune response that is activated and carried out by T lymphocytes; the counterpart to humoral immunity.
Inflammation or infection of the skin and tissues beneath the skin.
Pertaining to the cerebellum (the portion of the brain concerning the coordination of complex movements and balance).

A loss of motor coordination as a result of damage to the cerebellum or its pathways; may be manifested as a loss of balance in the entire body when moving or by unsteady movement of the arms or legs.
Neurologic sequela of infection with Plasmodium falciparum.
A focal infection or inflammation of the brain tissue.
Fluid surrounding the brain and spinal cord.
Pertaining to the neck or a necklike portion of an organ.
Inflammation of the mucous membranes or deeper structures of the cervix.
A nonvaginal delivery whereby the fetus is surgically removed via an incision through the lower abdominal wall and uterus.
The class of helminths that includes the tapeworms (e. g., Taenia sp.); these flatworms have a rounded head (scolex) followed by a chain of multiple segments (proglottids).
The primary lesion of syphilis; typically dull red, hard, and insensitive with a center that erodes and ulcerates, then heals slowly over a period of 4 to 6 weeks.
The use of chemicals such as antibiotics to prevent the occurrence of disease.
Migration of an organism or cell in response to a chemical gradient.
The use of drugs or chemical substances to treat disease.

Combining traits from two different species to create an organism with unique characteristics; in the context of bioterrorism, adding new virulence factors to a microorganism. This term is also used in the context of genetically engineered antibodies in which different parts of the antibody come from different animals.
A pliant, strong, glucose-derived polymer that composes the fungal cell wall.
Inflammation or infection of the bile ducts.
Surgical removal of the gall bladder.
Inflammation of the gall bladder.
Inflammation or infection of the chorion, amnion, amniotic fluid, and often the placental villi and decidua as well.
Inflammation or infection of the light-detecting layer (retina) and the underlying vascular tissue (choroid) beneath it in the back of the eye, which can lead to progressive impairment of vision.

A group of slowly progressive lung disorders that includes emphysema and chronic bronchitis; results in the marked decrease in airflow through the lungs with the main impact on the ability to exhale; the vast majority of cases are associated with cigarette smoke.
Motile organelles found in the respiratory tract and fallopian tubes, which facilitate mucus clearance.
Pathological process, usually induced by viral infections, that causes changes in the cilia such that they do not beat.
Destruction of a tissue or organ with loss of normal structure that is replaced with scar tissue; common in association with alcoholism, where it involves the liver.
A series of standardized decision points based on previous test results or signs and symptoms that are designed to optimize efficiency of testing and treatment.
Abnormal platelet aggregation and/or clotting of the blood.
A non-protein chemical that is necessary, in addition to an enzyme, to catalyze a reaction.
A designated group of individuals to be examined for a particular trait, exposure, or outcome.
Sexual intercourse.
Inflammation of the colon.
Portion of the gastrointestinal tract beginning at the cecum and continuing to the rectum; large intestines.
The presence of one or more bacterial species inhabiting an organ, surface, or foreign body.
Introduction of a light and camera through the anus to examine and sometimes biopsy the luminal surface of the colon.
Examination of the vulva, vagina, and uterine cervix with magnification.
Used to treat HIV infection; includes several medications with different mechanisms of action (see HAART).
A relationship between two organisms whereby one benefits and the other neither benefits nor is harmed.

Component of the immune system that consists of a set of proteins in the serum; the proteins are activated in a cascade fashion and assist in the process of phagocytosis, direct microbe destruction, and phagocyte recruitment.
The degree to which a patient follows the prescribed regimen of treatment.
A series of computer-processed radiographs that construct “slices” of images through the body.
A diagnostic test that is conducted after a positive screening test to confirm the illness or trait; a good confirmatory test should have a low rate of false-positive results.
Pertains to a condition developing at or before birth.
An infection by Treponema pallidum that occurs in a fetus before birth or during birth.
Type of bacterial vaccine in which a portion of the bacterial capsule is attached to an inactive toxin or protein to enhance the immune response to the capsule antigen.
Inflammation of the tissue protecting the front of the eye; often due to infection. Also called “pink eye.”
Nonmotile, asexual spores of fungi.
Decrease in frequency or amount of bowel movements or decreased water content of stools.
Inflammation of the skin caused by superficial contact with an allergen or chemical.

Protective measures used to prevent the transmission of diseases spread by contact with skin, mucous membranes, or bodily fluids, which require that providers wear a gown and gloves and practice appropriate hand hygiene.
An organism identified from culture of a body fluid or wound that is thought to be present because of inadequate aseptic sampling and not because of pathogenic infection.
The persistent presence of bacteria in the circulation.
Describes a structure or lesion that takes up oral or intravenous contrast dye, distinguishing it from surrounding tissues.
The period of time after a disease process has ended but before the return of optimal health.
A specimen that is collected from the patient either in the late stages of an acute infectious process or when it has ended.
The clear outer layer forming the front of the eye, continuous with the sclera and covering the iris and pupil.
Acute inflammation or infection of the nasal membranes, leading to a thin watery discharge from the nose, as seen with the common cold.
Pertaining to the ribs.
The area in the back where the last ribs join to their respective vertebrae.
The crackling sound (resembling the sound that occurs when rubbing hair between the fingers) that is heard in certain disease states.

An immune-mediated inflammatory disease most commonly observed in the terminal ileum, but which can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus. Granulomatous inflammation is a hallmark of the disease.
Binding of an antibody to an antigen other than the one against which it was developed.
The difficult, noisy respirations and hoarse cough that characterize laryngeal problems in children; this is often caused by parainfluenza virus.
An increase in adipose tissue (fat) in certain areas of the body, legs, and trunk. Purplish stripes (striae), especially on the abdomen, are also associated with Cushing's disease.
Of or pertaining to the skin.
Blue in color, associated with decreased oxygen saturation.
An abnormal membranous sac containing gas, fluid, or semisolid material. Also a dormant form of the protozoan life cycle that is capable of resisting destruction by heat or dehydration.
Larva of Taenia solium that is present in the tissue of the hosts.
Inflammation or infection of the urinary bladder; also called urinary tract infection (UTI). Associated with symptoms including painful urination, increased urination, and/or malodorous urine.
A hernia of the bladder; the hernia usually protrudes into the vagina.
Introduction of a light and camera into the bladder for examination or treatment.
One of a diverse group of chemicals produced by various cell types that regulate the immune response.
Relating to the study of cytology (the anatomy, physiology, pathology, and chemistry of the cell).
A substance or antibody that is capable of directly destroying a cell.
Changes in intracellular structures due to disease or toxins, usually leading to the death of the cell.
Destructive or damaging to a cell.
To remove devitalized tissue and/or foreign material from a wound.
Elimination of a potentially harmful microorganism colonizing an individual, regardless of whether it is causing an infection.

The position of a patient when lying down; lateral decubitus specifically refers to the patient's lying on his or her side. A decubitus wound is a wound that occurs as a result of pressure on an area, such as the heels or buttocks, because of the way the patient is lying.
Cysteine-rich peptides active against a wide range of microbial pathogens; produced by granulocytes and mucosal and epithelial cells.
The disappearance of fever.
A host that supports the adult, sexually reproducing form of a parasite.
Rupture of a surgically closed wound.
The loss of water resulting in the increased osmolarity of the body fluids.
A group of fungi that have dark hyphae, typically brown or black, with irregular branching.
A state of decreased mental capacity and orientation without a loss in consciousness; can be caused by toxins or by a gradual loss of normal brain tissue.
The area of skin that is served by one sensory spinal nerve.
One of the fungal organisms capable of infecting human skin, hair, or nails; includes the genera Microsporum, Trichophyton, and Epidermophyton.
The state of having unoccupied binding sites or the process of removing ligands from the binding sites; with hemoglobin, refers to a decrease in the amount of bound oxygen.
An acquired or congenital protrusion of abdominal contents through the diaphragm and into the thorax.
Increase in frequency or amount of bowel movements, or increased water content of stools.
A type of medium used to determine whether an organism demonstrates a specific characteristic.
A characteristic of certain fungi to exist in two distinct forms, such as yeast and mold.
Detection of an antigen by a fluorescently tagged antibody directly, rather than by an untagged primary antibody and subsequently by a fluorescent-tagged secondary antibody.
A type of therapy in which a responsible individual directly observes the patient taking the prescribed medications; utilized as a way to improve patient compliance.
Unsteady balance.
An assay that measures the distance of clearance around a disk impregnated with an antimicrobial solution placed on a lawn of bacteria.
The depletion of clotting elements in the blood, caused by many disease processes. Diffuse, severe hemorrhaging can occur; without treatment, it is often fatal.
Spread throughout the body.
Inflammation of intestinal diverticula.
Herniation of the intestinal mucosa through weaknesses in the muscle of the bowel, most commonly in the sigmoid colon.
An enzyme that introduces a negative supercoil into DNA to relieve strain as the DNA is being unwound by helicase.
A cellular or viral enzyme that synthesizes DNA from nucleotides.
Referring to the back or posterior aspect of a tissue or organ.
Group of nerve cell bodies outside the spinal cord that convey sensory impulses to the brain.
Also called diplopia, the perception of seeing a single object as two separate images.
Protective measures used to prevent the transmission of diseases spread by droplets, requiring providers to wear a surgical mask.
Whole-cell vaccine that contains toxoids to diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis.
Acellular vaccine that contains toxoids to diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis.

A condition marked by frequent watery stools usually containing blood and mucus; often accompanied by pain, fever, and dehydration; typically the result of amebic, bacillary, helminthic, or viral infections.
Gastric indigestion (upset stomach) due to alterations of gastric function that are caused by various disorders of the stomach.
Abnormal cell growth and division that is not malignant but which may evolve into malignancy.
The sensation of having difficulty breathing; also called shortness of breath. Dyspnea on exertion is shortness of breath that begins during strenuous movement.
Abnormal, involuntary muscle contractions that cause abnormal movements or postures.
Difficulty or pain on urination.
Purplish lesions of the skin and mucous membranes due to hemorrhage beneath the tissues; greater than 1 cm in size, lesions may be flat or raised.
Antifungal drugs that inhibit synthesis of the cell wall polysaccharide glucan.
A real-time, noninvasive study that utilizes ultrasound to evaluate the heart tissue, heart valves, great vessels, and corresponding blood flow.
A parasite that lives on the outside of its host.
Type of pregnancy in which the embryo implants outside the uterus; this usually occurs in the fallopian tube.
An itchy, scaly, blistery, or raised rash often seen in children and associated with irritation of the skin.
An accumulation of large amounts of extracellular watery fluid in tissues throughout the body.

The presence of excess fluid in the tissues or a cavity; for example, referred to as pleural effusion when excess fluid is found in the pleural cavity around the lungs, usually as a result of inflammation, infection, or malignancy.
A protease enzyme that breaks down elastin, a component of connective tissue.
Test used to represent electrical currents associated with muscles; used in the diagnosis of neuromuscular diseases.

An object in the bloodstream that becomes dislodged and carried until becoming trapped in a different vessel; may be a thrombus, immune complex of microorganisms, air, foreign object, fat, or amniotic fluid; leads to partial or complete occlusion of the blood vessel.
Vomiting.
Type of therapy that is employed when the causative agent or the antibiotic susceptibility of the organism is not definitively known.
The collection of purulent material in the pleural space.
A mucous membrane eruption; typically occurs in relation to the skin eruptions that are symptoms of acute viral or coccal disease (see exanthem).
Inflammation of the brain.
Referring to the pathological condition of encephalitis.
Describes the presence of a disease that persists in a community or group of people.
Inflammation or infection of the tissue lining the inside of the heart; usually involves the heart valves.
Collection of cells from the endocervical canal for cytological, microbiologic, or molecular genetic testing.

The process of internalizing external substances by fusion with the plasma membrane and formation of an intracellular vesicle; is specifically considered phagocytosis if the internalized substance is solid.
A property of substances that originate from within an organism.
Inflammation or infection of the lining of the uterus.
Inflammation of the aqueous and/or vitreous humor of the eye.

Procedure involving the passing of a flexible hollow tube into the esophagus or rectum for the purpose of visualizing portions of the gastrointestinal tract; also useful for obtaining diagnostic samples.
Referring to the cells lining blood vessels.
A lipopolysaccharide on the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria; has many possible biological effects on the infected host, including activation of the clotting cascade, shock, or death.
A tube introduced through the mouth into the trachea to deliver oxygen and to clear carbon dioxide in a patient who cannot maintain his own airway.
Within the lumen of the blood vessels.
Relating to the intestine.
The absorptive epithelial cells that line the lumen of the intestine.
Exotoxin that causes fluid secretion in the gut.

Referring to a temporal pattern of disease occurrence in an animal population that is marked by predictable regularity with little change over time; for example, the pattern of hantavirus infection in deer mice.

A diagnostic test in which a specific antibody is linked to an enzyme; in a positive test, the antibody is attached to the antigen being tested for with a subsequent reaction by the linked enzyme; the enzyme reaction leads to a noticeable change, such as a change in color.
Increased number of eosinophils (a type of leukocyte) in the blood, often associated with parasitic infections.
An unexpectedly large number of cases of a disease or illness in a community.
Inflammation or infection of the epididymis.
Relating to the area of the abdomen that lies between the margins of the ribs.
Inflammation or infection of the flexible flap of tissue that covers the larynx during swallowing.
An extrachromosomal piece of DNA that is capable of being replicated independently of the host chromosome and integrated within the host DNA.
Describes a macrophage that resembles an epithelial cell.
The portion of an antigen recognized by an antibody.
The region surrounding the medial trochlea of the ulna.
Reddening, usually of the skin or mucous membranes.
A mild facial rash in children that has a “slapped cheek” appearance; usually caused by parvovirus B19.
A circular red rash that has a “bull's-eye” appearance due to the repeating red rings within an expanding outer ring; forms at the site of a tick bite and is indicative of Lyme disease.
Relating to erythema.
The rate at which red blood cells settle to the bottom of a test tube. A marker of systemic inflammation.
Inflammation of the esophagus.
Introduction of a light and camera through the mouth to examine and sometimes biopsy the luminal surface of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum.
Air-filled cavity in the ethmoid bone located below the orbit of the eye and beside the nose.
Excision of the cells of the ethmoid sinus to create a single large cavity.
The cause of a disease or process.
An increase in the symptoms of a disease.
A skin rash that occurs as a symptom of acute viral or bacterial infection (see enanthem).
A process whereby intracellular vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane in order to empty their contents into the extracellular space.
Pertaining to substances that originate from outside an organism.
Proteins secreted by bacteria that have toxic effects on mammalian cells.
Ejection of secretions from the lungs or throat by coughing.
The surface of a joint involved in extension or straightening of a limb.
Outwardly visible genitalia, including the penis and scrotum in males and the vulva and vaginal introitus in females.
Inflammation of the external auditory canal and/or auricle.
Not confined to one dermatome.
Referring to the outer side of the dura mater.
Air outside of the confines of the intestinal wall, a sign of bowel perforation.
Outside the medulla oblongata (brain stem), in reference to the cranial nerves.
Outside of the parenchyma.
Fluid resulting from inflammation or infection; contains an increased number of cells and an increased amount of protein and other cellular debris.
Refers to an organism that can readily grow under either aerobic or anaerobic conditions.
A test result of negative when the true result is positive.
A test result of positive when the true result is negative.
Fibrous connective tissue dividing muscle layers, neurovascular structures, and body cavities.
Describes a type of organism with complex nutritional requirements; requires special media for laboratory culture.
Relating to fever.
Mode of transmission.
Foul smelling.
Replacement of normal tissue by excess fibrous tissue.
The third larval stage of the intestinal nematodes; this stage is infectious and nonfeeding.
Appendages on the surface of bacteria that allow for attachment and infection; same as pili.
An abnormal communication between hollow organs or vessels, or between a hollow organ or vessel and the skin.
A loss of muscle function with a resulting absence of muscle tone.
A cellular appendage on some prokaryotic and eukaryotic unicellular organisms that is used for motility and sometimes has a sensory role as well.
Pain in the posterolateral aspects of the trunk.
A wave-like motion felt on palpation, due to underlying fluid content.
A technique in magnetic resonance imaging that suppresses cerebrospinal fluid to improve visualization of periventricular lesions.
The administration of large-volume crystalloid and/or colloid fluids to maintain adequate perfusion in the setting of shock.
Infection of hair follicles.
An object that is capable of transmitting an organism from one location to another, for example, toys, clothing, utensils, or hairbrushes.
Soft area between the cranial bones of an infant's skull, indicative of areas not yet ossified.
A tissue sample typically used during a surgical procedure to allow rapid diagnosis during the operation.
Referring to the sudden occurrence of an intense or severe process.
The presence of fungi in the bloodstream.
Infection involving a hair follicle resulting in a skin boil.
The reflex arc mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve sensing posterior pharyngeal irritation, which stimulates the vagus nerve to elevate the soft palate and contract the pharyngeal muscles.
Manner of walking.
Polysaccharides of mannose with galactose side chains found in Aspergillus spp. Used to diagnose invasive disease caused by this organism.
A group of nerve cell bodies located in the peripheral nervous system.
Necrosis due to any cause (for example, obstructed, diminished, or lost blood flow); may be localized or widespread; may be dry or wet.
Life-threatening necrotic infection of soft tissue by gas-forming bacteria, most commonly Clostridium perfringens.
Inflammation of the stomach, usually involving only the lining inside the organ.
Inflammation of the mucous membrane lining of both the stomach and the intestine.
A complete unit of genetic information that encodes a single protein.
A DNA sequence that is designed to covalently bond to a target gene.
Sex organs.
Genetic makeup of an individual or microorganism.
Pertaining to an organism with a preference for the soil.
The interval between fertilization of a female and birth of the offspring.
Bilateral inflammatory changes of the glomeruli that are the result of renal disease.
A complication of bone marrow transplant or transfusion of nonirradiated blood products in which immune cells from the donor destroy host cells.
A sequence of dyes and solvents applied to bacteria to enable viewing under the microscope; organisms stain either Gram positive or Gram negative.
Regenerating, vascular tissue growing from the bed of a healing wound.
A collection of leukocytes, macrophages, and specialized cells of the reticuloendothelial system surrounding a focal area of chronic inflammation or infection; usually forms a nodular mass.
Pertaining to or resembling a granuloma.
Pregnant, carrying eggs or a fetus.
A reagent used to test for occult blood, usually in the feces.
Voluntary or involuntary flexion of the abdominal wall muscles in response to an examiner palpating the abdomen; a sign of peritonitis.

Inflammation of peripheral nerves leading to increasing weakness or paralysis; most often occurs in more distal areas before affecting more proximal portions of the body; may progress to the point where the patient requires support on a ventilator because of weakness of the respiratory muscles.
Highly active antiretroviral therapy, used to treat HIV infection; includes several medications with different mechanisms of action (see combination antiretroviral therapy [cART]).
Extremophile organism that grows in high salt concentrations.
A group of flatworms and roundworms that derive their nutrients from parasitizing a living host.
Vomiting blood.
Amount of red blood cells (erythrocytes) in a given volume of blood; usually expressed as a percentage or fraction.
Refers to anything produced by, derived from, or spread via the blood.
A collection of blood within an extravascular space such as an organ, a tissue area, or a potential space; the blood displays various colors and degrees of organization; a bruise.

The transplant of multipotent hematopoietic cells from donor bone marrow, peripheral blood, or cord blood and administration to a recipient. Transplants can be autologous (harvested from the patient and given to the same patient after toxic therapies) or allogenic (harvested from a related or unrelated human leukocyte antigen matched donor and given to the patient).
The presence of blood in the urine.
The left or right half of the chest.
An increase in the number of red blood cells per unit volume of plasma.
Extracorporeal removal of wastes and/or toxins from the blood in states of acute or chronic renal failure, or other medical conditions where rapid clearance is necessary.
The movement of blood through the vasculature, measured for example by blood pressure, heart rate, and contractility; an important component of oxygen delivery to the tissues.
Disorders or diseases that are the result of abnormalities of hemoglobin structure; for example, sickle cell disease and thalassemia.
Proteins or lipids that cause lysis of red blood cells in laboratory media, but not necessarily in vivo; useful for classifying bacterial species.
Destruction or breakdown of red blood cells.
Coughing up (expectoration) of blood or blood-streaked sputum.
Bleeding; can be either external or internal, e. g., intracranial hemorrhage.
Massive blood loss resulting in inadequate delivery of oxygen to the tissues, leading to cell death and multisystem organ failure.
Systemic vasculitis caused by immune complexes of IgA, characterized by cutaneous purpura, arthritis, abdominal pain, and renal disease; most commonly presents in children and is self-limited.
Inflammation of hepatic (liver) cells.
Functional cells of the liver.
Enlargement of the liver.
Enlargement of the liver and spleen.
Part of an anatomical structure that has partially expanded out of its normal confined area.
A disease caused by the coxsackievirus group B; results in fever and ulcers of the palate.
Antibodies produced by an organism that react to antigens present on cells in another species.
An organism that contains two different alleles for a particular gene.
The area of an organ where the nerves and vessels enter and exit; the lungs, kidneys, lymph nodes, ovaries, and spleen all have hilar areas.
Microscopic evaluation of tissue.
Inability of cells to utilize oxygen, in spite of normal oxygen delivery to the tissues.
The body's ability to regulate variables so that a stable state is achieved in a wide range of external conditions.
Passage of disease from person to person or by contact with infected materials.
Referring to substances in the blood; in the immune system, this refers to antibodies to help fight disease rather than the cellular portion that involves leukocytes.
An immune response that is activated and carried out by B lymphocytes and involving specific antibodies; the counterpart to cell-mediated immunity.
An enzyme that catalyzes the degradation of hyaluronic acid, a component of the extracellular matrix.
The annealing of a fluorescently labeled DNA probe to a target sequence that can then be detected by microscopy or chemical reactions.
Possible sequela of Echinococcus infection; cysts are most commonly present in the liver or lungs.

Condition characterized by a large accumulation of fluid in the cerebral ventricles; results in increased intracranial pressure and dilatation of the cerebral ventricles. It can also occur secondarily as a result of loss of brain tissue.
General term for the accumulation of clear, watery fluid in spaces or cavities throughout the body.
Accumulation of fluid in the pleural, pericardial, or peritoneal cavities, as well as in the subcutaneous tissues of a fetus, usually resulting from anemia.
Delivery of higher than atmospheric pressures of oxygen in a pressurized chamber, used to enhance wound healing and to treat infections.
The presence of abnormally high levels of cholesterol in the blood.
A disease that is persistently present at high prevalence.
Donor plasma with high titers of antibody against a particular antigen.
Infection caused by very large numbers of organisms that results from an immunodeficient state.
Abnormal increased functional residual volume in the lungs.
An organism or gene with abnormally frequent mutations.
Abnormally high blood pressure.
Abnormally increased respiratory rate, or tidal volume, or both, resulting in abnormally decreased dissolved carbon dioxide, increased bicarbonate, and alkalosis if no compensations are made.
The tube-like structures visible with a microscope that make up filamentous fungi.
A dormant phase of a Plasmodium vivax or P. ovale infection; hypnozoites are located in hepatocytes and are responsible for late-onset relapse.
Abnormally decreased production of IgG.
Abnormally low concentrations of sodium in the circulating blood.

Pertaining to a decrease in the amount of hormones produced by the anterior (forward) portion of the pituitary gland; involves hormones that affect growth, steroid production, thyroid gland function, and reproduction.
The underdevelopment of tissues or organs as a result of either atrophy or a decrease in the number of cells.
Abnormally decreased deep-tendon reflexes.
Abnormally low blood pressure.
Abnormally low body temperature.
Abnormally decreased muscular tone.
Low oxygen content in the blood.
See jaundice.
Dilatation and weakening of the heart muscle with no known cause.
An immune-mediated disease characterized by low platelet counts with normal bone marrow and no other primary conditions associated with low platelets.
The most distal portion of the small intestine, site of absorption of many important nutrients and vitamins.
Antigen bound by specific antibodies with or without activated complement; may become insoluble and deposit in the vessel walls, including those of the glomeruli (see glomerulonephritis) or tissue.
Targeted therapies that work to selectively block steps involved in the inflammatory response.
In patients with significant immune compromise (usually seen in advanced HIV), the recovery of immune function may cause an overwhelming inflammatory response and worsen disease symptoms.
The process of exposing an organism to an antigen with the intent of generating immunological memory.

An assay that uses antibodies to first detect an analyte and then to exhibit a colored stripe to show the presence of the analyte; can be used rapidly with no further preparation, commonly for at-home or point-of-care testing.

A general term indicating an increased susceptibility to infection. May be due to defects in cell-mediated immunity, as occur with advanced HIV disease and posttransplant immunosuppressive medications; defects in neutrophil number or function, as occur following cancer chemotherapy; defects in humoral immunity, as occur in immunoglobulin deficiencies; or other immune defects such as deficiencies in splenic function.
Y-shaped proteins, produced by plasma cells, which have unique epitopes that recognize particular antigens and mark them for destruction.
Treatment of a disease by enhancing, suppressing, or changing the immune system.
Protection from a disease by active or passive immunization.
The decline in function of the immune system with age, leading to increased rates of infection, neoplasia, and autoimmune disorders.
Decreased activity or magnitude of the immune response, caused by illness or drugs.
Pertaining to an agent or disease that prevents or interferes with the immune system response.
Infection of previously damaged skin by group A streptococci or staphylococci; lesions usually drain honey-colored fluid.
Inside the womb.
A host from which a parasite cannot be transmitted to a definitive host.
Phagocytized pathogens contained within a phagosome that cannot be effectively degraded and excreted.
Nearly or completely painless, sluggish, or inactive; used to describe a disease process.

A clinical sample of secretions from the tracheobronchial tree that is produced by having the patient inhale an irritating aerosol; the presence of macrophages or inflammatory cells suggests an adequate sample, whereas the presence of squamous epithelial cells suggests contamination by the upper respiratory tract.
A molecule that inhibits a repressor or promotes an activator, resulting in increased transcription of a particular gene.
Chromosomal resistance genes that are expressed only in the presence of a specific antimicrobial agent.
Chemotherapy given as the initial treatment for a malignancy, sometimes followed by surgery, radiation, or additional chemotherapy treatments.
Firmness in soft tissue.
Tissue death often due to an interruption in the blood supply to that tissue.
The invasion and growth of a disease-causing microorganism within a host.
The number of microorganisms inoculated into a host necessary to cause disease.
The inability to produce viable offspring; may be due to dysfunctional germ cells or to a structural abnormality.
The invasion of the spaces in a tissue by materials not usually found in the tissue, such as tumors, infectious agents, and white blood cells.
A series of chemical and physical processes within a tissue in response to toxins, foreign antigens, or injury; involves various cells of the vasculature, connective tissue, and immune system.
The creation of negative intrathoracic pressure that causes air to move into the lungs. Infectious agents may be obtained in this manner.
Nonspecific and nonadaptive first line of defense against infection; includes skin and physical barriers, humoral and cell-mediated immunity, and the inflammatory response.
Describes a disease that causes harm in a gradual way.
Transmembrane cell surface proteins that facilitate binding of cells to surfaces or other cells.
A cytokine produced by white blood cells in response to viral infection.
A test that measures interferon gamma released by a patient's white blood cells after exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis antigens.
A group of cytokines whose role in the immune response includes cell differentiation, growth, and motility.
A host in which a parasite is capable of completing only part of its life cycle.
Pertaining to spaces between the components of a tissue; in the lungs, refers to spaces between the lung parenchyma.
The spaces where the skin of two surfaces may touch.
The state of experiencing deleterious effects of toxin ingestion or dissemination.
Within the skull.
Within the skin.
During labor or delivery.
Within the peritoneal cavity.
Inside the cavity of the womb, as for a fetus.
Innate ability of a pathogen to resist antimicrobial therapy.
The placement of a tubular device from the oro- or nasopharyngeal cavity into the trachea in order to assist with ventilation.
The prolapse of a distal part of an organ back into the proximal portion of the same organ; usually refers to a portion of the intestine, where it may result in obstruction.

Cellular injury due to a decreased delivery of oxygen to a tissue because of either the impairment of blood flow to the tissue or decreased oxygen content of the blood. This may progress to cellular death.
0.9% or 154 mM solution of sodium chloride used to replete intravascular volume.

Yellow cast of the skin and mucous membranes due to an increase of bilirubins (bile breakdown products) that occurs when the liver is unable to clear these chemicals from the blood; often due to toxic or infectious hepatitis; also referred to as icterus.
Pertains to skin that has an outer covering of keratin.
Inflammation of the cornea.
Inflammation of the cornea and conjunctiva.
A sign of meningeal irritation, elicited when flexion of the hip causes involuntary flexion of the neck.

A series of four criteria that should be met to establish that a microorganism is causative of a disease process: (i) the organism is isolated from hosts with the disease and absent in healthy hosts; (ii) the organism can be grown in culture; (iii) the organism can then be injected in a healthy host and cause disease; (iv) the organism can then be isolated from the newly inoculated host.
Small red spots with a white center that are located on the inside of the cheek; pathognomonic for measles.
A small duct that carries fluids (tears) from the lacrimal gland to the surface of the eyeball.
A glycoprotein secreted from exocrine glands that is part of the innate immune system and has antiviral, antibacterial, and antiparasitic properties in addition to a role in iron binding.
The inability of the body to produce enough lactase to adequately metabolize lactose.
Developmental stage of the helminths, resembling a small immature worm.
Inflammation of the larynx (voice box).
Inflammation of the larynx and larger airways.
A procedure that reshapes the cornea with a laser to correct vision.
Referring to any organism or disease that is quiescent but is capable of being reactivated.
Type of infection in which the organism or virus is present but not producing an inflammatory response.
An assay that uses antibody-coated latex beads; the presence of the antigen causes aggregation of the beads.
Drowsiness or decreased responsiveness.

General term used to describe a group of malignancies of either lymphoid or hematopoietic origin; progressive proliferation of abnormal leukocytes can be found in the blood, the hematopoietic tissues, and other organs.

An increase in white blood cell counts similar to the profile seen in leukemia; can be caused by infections (particularly diphtheria, pertussis, Clostridioides difficile, and viral mononucleosis), drugs, and other medical conditions.
A pore-forming cytotoxin produced by certain bacteria.
An enzyme produced by active white blood cells; a sensitive screening test for infection in the urinary tract.
Encephalitis that is restricted to the white matter of the brain.
Decreased number of white blood cells.
An elevation in white blood cell count above 50–100,000 cells per μl that impairs normal blood flow and causes ischemia and hemorrhage.
Found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria; lost in the decolorizing step of Gram staining so that the Gram-negative cells do not stain with crystal violet.
A procedure that excises dysplastic lesions of the uterine cervix by using an electrified wire loop.
A procedure that is used to obtain cerebrospinal fluid for diagnostic purposes, performed by introducing a needle into the lumbar region of the subarachnoid space.

An autoimmune disease that can affect a wide variety of structures, including the skin, joints, kidneys, lungs, heart, blood cells and vessels, and nervous system, and can have reproductive consequences.
Abnormal enlargement of the lymph nodes.
The collection of vessels, lymph nodes, and spleen that composes the lymph system.
An increase in the number of lymphocytes above normal.

A sexually transmitted infection caused by type L1, L2, L2a, or L3 Chlamydia trachomatis that causes genital ulcers, inflammation of the inguinal lymph nodes, and inflammation of other structures in the pelvis.
A malignant neoplasm of lymphocytes and their precursors that typically presents as a solid tumor.
Any one of a group of cancers involving cells from which white blood cells or platelets are derived; includes lymphomas, leukemias, and multiple myeloma.

A stable and heritable characteristic of bacteria to produce and release bacteriophage as a result of a prophage within the bacterium; the prophage can be either integrated into the bacterial genome or maintained as a plasmid.
Large, multinucleated conidia.
Pertaining to lesions that are flat and that are often detected only by a change in color or texture of the lesion compared with surrounding normal tissue.
Pertaining to lesions with properties that are both macular and papular.
Condition in which substances are not absorbed properly; usually occurs in the intestine, where it results in excessive loss of water or nutrients in the stool.
An increase in the total number or volume of stools due to a decrease in the absorption of nutrients (especially fats and fat-soluble vitamins) in the small intestine.
Generalized feeling of discomfort caused by many disease processes.
Clinical manifestation of infection by the mosquito-borne Plasmodium genus, characterized by cyclic hemolysis, fevers, and sometimes splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and encephalopathy.
Abnormal collection of cells with a tendency to grow in a rapid, unregulated, and uncontrolled fashion.
Inflammation or infection of the external auditory canal and/or auricle that is aggressive and difficult to treat.
Characteristic of a long-standing diet with inadequate calories, nutrients, or both.

A screening test for tuberculosis in which a protein is injected into the dermis; a type IV sensitivity reaction causes induration of the injection site in a patient who has been exposed to tuberculosis.
An analytical technique that produces a spectrum of the masses and charges of atoms or molecules in a sample.
Infection or inflammation of the breast tissue.
Inflammation of a collection of lymph nodes that are not individually palpable or mobile.
Multidrug-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis; characterized by resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampin.
Excretion of black, tarry stools containing blood that has been altered by intestinal substances.
Thin, tough tissue surrounding the brain and spinal cord.
Inflammation of the meninges.
Inflammation of the brain and surrounding membranes (meninges).
Relating to the conical portion of long bones that lies between the epiphysis and diaphysis.
The occurrence of disease at sites distant from and not connected directly with the site where the disease first appeared; this process is seen with malignancies and infections.
Minimum inhibitory concentration; the lowest concentration of a drug needed to inhibit the growth of a microorganism.
Pertaining to an atmosphere with a reduced concentration of oxygen; some microorganisms, called microaerophiles, grow best in such an environment.
The collective genome of the microorganisms colonizing a host.
The microorganisms that colonize a host, including the microorganisms in the gastrointestinal tract, genitourinary tract, mouth, and skin for example.
The part of the circulation that includes the smallest vessels; typically refers to the capillaries.
Disseminated tuberculosis, with small lesions in both the lungs and extrapulmonary organs.

Any condition of the mitral valve between the left atrium and left ventricle that allows blood to flow back into the atrium when the ventricle contracts; normally, the valve shuts tightly, allowing no flow of blood back into the atrium; often heard as a heart murmur during auscultation.

A defect in the valve between the left atrium and ventricle caused by a weakening of the tough connective tissue of the valve leaflets, which allows the valve to project back into the left atrium; during normal function, the valve closes tightly during ventricular contraction.
Describes changes made to a typical Ziehl-Neelsen or Kinyoun stain, typically in the acid wash step, to detect acid-fast organisms such as Isospora, Cyclospora, or Nocardia.
Antibodies that are cloned to target a particular epitope.
Harmful effects of a condition or treatment, excluding death.
Rash that resembles the flat to slightly raised (maculopapular) lesions seen in measles.
Study of the structure, form, or shape.
The ability of an organism to have self-propelled motion.
Highly glycosylated, negatively charged proteins that give secretions lubrication and the ability to bind pathogens and irritants.
Pertaining to the movement of a mucous layer resting on a ciliated epithelium, part of the innate immune system of the respiratory system.
Involving the skin and mucous membranes.
Pertaining to or resembling mucus.
An invasive infection caused by Mucorales order fungi that most commonly affects the mouth, sinuses, and brain.
The portion of the immune system that protects the mucosal membranes from pathogens.
Describes a collection of fluid in multiple noncommunicating pockets separated by septa or fibrosis.
Normal or abnormal sounds heard on auscultation of the heart or vessels; this is a physical finding that has a variety of causes.
An error in genome replication that can be advantageous, deleterious, or neutral on an organism's ability to grow and reproduce.
Soreness or aching of muscles.
A ball of fungus, commonly Aspergillus, found in pre-existing cavitary lesions of the lungs.
Cancer of well-differentiated immunoglobulin-producing cells; progressive proliferation of plasma cells is seen with this type of malignancy.
A disease of the neural tissue of the spinal cord.
Inflammation of heart muscle cells.
Necrosis of muscle tissue.
Inflammation of the muscle.
Nostrils.
Pertaining to the nasal and pharyngeal cavities.
Death of cells, tissues, or portions of organs that results from irreversible injury; several different types of necrosis can be distinguished.
A destructive soft tissue infection that causes necrosis of the superficial fascia and surrounding tissues; this is often a fulminant process and one that may be difficult to diagnose.
The proportion of patients who do not have a disease who will test negative by a given assay.

A confinement room that has a lower atmospheric pressure than the surrounding rooms; a pressure gradient prevents air from escaping into occupied areas; necessary for the containment of airborne pathogens, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
The class of helminths that includes the roundworms Ascaris, Enterobius, and Strongyloides spp.
A newborn infant.
Degeneration of renal tubular epithelium.
Property of a toxin or drug that results in damage to the kidney.
A stabbing pain that follows the course of a nerve.
Glycoside hydrolase enzyme on the influenza virus that cleaves sialic acid from cell surface, facilitating release of new virions from infected host cells.
Diseases or disorders affecting the cranial nerves or the peripheral or autonomic nervous systems.
A possible manifestation of tertiary syphilis with a wide range of presentations, including meningitis, tabes dorsalis, Argyll Robertson pupils, cerebrovascular disease, and dementia.
An antibody that binds to a particle, usually a virus or toxin, to prevent it from being infectious or hazardous.
Abnormally low numbers of neutrophils in the circulating blood.
The most common type of white blood cell, neutrophils phagocytize antigens and contain myeloperoxidase-filled granules; part of innate immunity and the inflammatory response.
A test performed on dried blood samples 24 hours after birth that screens for serious disorders that can be improved with treatment.
Referring to night.
Describing knotlike or raised solid lesions of the skin or other organs.
Characteristic of a patient who is unable or chooses not to adhere to prescribed therapy.
Consequences of an infection that are associated with the body's immune response to the organism rather than with the infection itself.
Disease characterized by impaired glucose clearance and insulin resistance; managed with diet or oral medications.
Characteristic of infections that do not invade multiple tissues or cause disseminated tissue destruction.
Characteristic of infections or conditions that do not result in the production of pus.
Complications, caused by a previous disease status, that do not involve purulence.
Not producing a toxin.
Describing the condition of having normal blood pressure; the usual readings seen in adults are between 90/50 and 150/90 mm Hg.
Health care-associated; any condition resulting from a person's hospital stay; usually used in the context of an infection acquired as a result of hospitalization.
Stiffness of the neck, often associated with meningitis.
A molecular technique that uses methods of amplification of nucleic acids, like PCR, to detect microorganisms or other genetic targets.
An intermediate life cycle stage in some insects and arachnids, following the larval stage and preceding the adult stage.
Characteristic of an organism that can only reproduce inside a host cell.
A block along the path (of the intestines or a blood vessel).
Serving to block the flow of air or liquid.
Blood present in body fluids, such as stool, that cannot be detected with the naked eye; the most commonly used test for occult blood is a guaiac test.
Of or pertaining to the eye.
Short segments of RNA or DNA that can be used to identify genes of interest in amplification tests, microarrays, and fluorescent in situ hybridization assays.
The property of having the potential to cause malignant neoplasm.
Motile tapeworm embryos that are released from the egg after the egg is ingested by a suitable host.
A cyst containing zygotes of a parasite that can be transmitted to a suitable host.
An area of clouding or obscuring that decreases the penetrance of light.
The pressure of the cerebrospinal fluid measured upon entry during a lumbar puncture.
Describes a spastic state in which the head and heels are arched backward and the torso extends outward.
An infection caused by an organism capable of causing disease only in individuals whose resistance to infection is lowered.
Pertaining to an agent (typically an antibody) that, when bound to an antigen such as bacterial polysaccharide capsule, enhances the ingestion of the antigen by white blood cells.
Describes proteins, including some antibodies and complement proteins, which tag an antigen for destruction by phagocytosis.
The reversal of dehydration by drinking a solution of water, electrolytes, and carbohydrates.
Abnormal enlargement of the organs; visceromegaly.
A normal anatomical opening, such as the mouth.
Pertaining to the mouth and lips.
Pertaining to the oral and pharyngeal cavities.
Decreased blood pressure caused by sitting up or by standing erect; often seen in patients who are dehydrated.
Pertaining to the bones and joints.
Inflammation or infection of bone.
Inflammation of the middle ear; visualized with an otoscope, which often shows the presence of fluid or pus behind the eardrum.
Refers to a substance that has a toxic effect on the ear; some antibiotics, for example, have this property.
Referring to the palate, the bony or soft tissue roof of the oral cavity.
A technique used during physical examination that involves the use of the hands to feel for organs, abnormal masses, pulses, or vibrations.
Inflammation throughout the colon.
Inflammation of the pancreas.
A significant reduction in the number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets in the circulating blood.
Relating to a disease that is affecting the population of an extensive region, country, continent, or the entire world.
Pertaining to lesions that are raised and well circumscribed.
Four paired sinuses—frontal, ethmoidal, sphenoid, and maxillary—found in the skull.
Weakness of the legs.
An organism that lives in or on and derives its nutritional support from a host.
Presence of parasites in the blood.
Beside a vertebra or the vertebral column.
Cells of a gland or organ that are contained within and supported by the surrounding connective tissue network.
Describes the means of administering medication, nutrition, or fluids by vein, rather than the digestive tract.
Incomplete paralysis.
The abrupt episodic recurrence of disease or disease symptoms; also, a spasm or fit.
Any microorganism that causes disease.
The mechanism by which a microorganism causes disease.

A small portion of a bacterial chromosome that includes many of the genes necessary for infection; the physical closeness of these genes suggests that the bacterium obtained infectious capability from a single source or process.
The area of the bacterial chromosome that includes the genes required for infection.
Symptoms or lesions characteristic of a single disease process, on the basis of which a diagnosis can be determined.
A laboratory technique for rapidly replicating DNA strands in a test tube; can be used for diagnosis when a probe specific for an exact sequence of DNA is used to initiate the replication process.
Inflammation of the female reproductive organs, typically due to infection.
The main component of the bacterial cell wall; composed of carbohydrates and amino acids.
Determining the properties of a structure by tapping over the structure.
Through the skin.
An abnormal opening.
The area surrounding the anus.
Inflammation of the sac covering the heart.
Around or near the hila of the lungs.
The period of time immediately preceding and following birth.
Around the eye socket (orbit).
The tough tissue surrounding the surface of any bone.
Inflammation of the periosteum (the thick fibrous membrane that covers the surface of the bone, except for the articular cartilage).
Pain, numbness, or tingling in the extremities as a result of inflammation of or injury to the peripheral nerves.
The alternating waves of contraction and relaxation within the gastrointestinal tract that propel its contents onward.
Inflammation of the peritoneum (the thin lining of mesothelium and connective tissue that lines the abdominal cavity).
A collection of pus in the area surrounding the tonsils.
Pertaining to the area surrounding the navel (umbilicus).
Pertaining to the area surrounding the urethra.
Pinpoint, flat lesions due to hemorrhage of blood into tissues under the skin or mucous membranes.
Small, pinpoint, and flat lesions of the skin and mucous membranes associated with hemorrhage beneath the tissue; similar to purpura, except the lesions seen with purpura are larger.
Lymphatic tissues in the walls of the large intestine.
The process by which cells ingest and digest solid substances such as tissue debris, bacteria, or foreign material.
A phagosome fused with a lysosome for degradation of its contents.
A vacuole formed upon phagocytosis of a particle, eventually fused with a lysosome for degradation.
A long bone of the finger.
The study of the ways in which a patient's genome affects his or her response to specific drugs. Used commonly in selecting cancer chemotherapeutic agents.
Inflammation of the pharynx, the muscular tube connecting the nose and mouth to the esophagus and larynx; sore throat.
Pertaining to the effects of an organism's genes and the environment on its physical appearance, biochemistry, and physiology.
Abnormal sensitivity to light.
The desire to eat inappropriate and nonnutritional substances such as soil.
Colored.
Appendages on the surface of bacteria that allow for attachment and infection; same as fimbriae.
Patient becoming reinfected with an infectious agent after treatment because the patient's infected close contacts have not been treated.
Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly Pneumocystis carinii) pneumonia.
A treatment with no active medication, only approved for use in investigating the effects of a novel medication by comparing the test drug to the placebo.
A technique used to treat certain malignancies and autoimmune disorders, in which a patient's plasma is removed and replaced with equal volume of plasma or other colloid.

A piece of DNA that is physically separate from the host's chromosome and not essential for survival; often a means for bacteria to acquire a new function such as antibiotic resistance or toxin production.
The presence of abnormally large numbers of cells; often refers to the increase in white blood cells that occurs during an infection.
Chest pain that is caused by irritation or inflammation of the pleura, characterized by worsening pain upon inspiration.
Inflammation of the pleura.
Episodic pain due to transient spasms of the intercostal muscles (muscles between the ribs that assist in respiration), caused by irritation of the pleura.
Functional cells of the lung.
Infection of the lung parenchyma.
Inflammation of the lungs.
Inflammation and destruction of the gray matter of the spinal cord, possibly resulting in paralysis; causative agents are the polioviruses.
An autoimmune disease that causes inflammation of small and medium-sized arteries.
Pertaining to multiple different microorganisms.
Variants of a particular gene.
The circulation of blood to the liver from the small intestine, the right half of the colon, and the spleen via the portal vein.
The site where microorganisms enter a host.
The probability of having a disease given a positive test result.
Referring to a patient's condition following a seizure; many people are less alert, and transient neurologic findings may be observed.
The condition or period of time after the delivery of a fetus.

Consequences of infection by group A streptococci that appear after the initial infection; these processes are not a direct result of the organism but rather are due to the host immune response to the organism.
Hyperplasia, premalignant or malignant polyclonal or monoclonal neoplasms of lymphocytes following solid-organ or stem-cell transplant.
A diagnostic test in which purified protein derivative is placed just under the skin; used to determine if patients are infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
An antibody that binds with its antigen and causes the antigen-antibody complex to precipitate from solution.
Genetic or acquired susceptibilities to a disease.

A condition of the late stages of pregnancy caused by accumulation of toxins in the blood; characterized by high blood pressure, swelling of the hands and feet, and the presence of proteins in the urine. If seizures occur, it becomes known as eclampsia.
Initiating antiviral therapy for patients who exhibit viremia.
The likelihood of a patient having a particular disease before any testing.
The number of people at a given period of time with a given trait or disease divided by the number of people at risk for the trait or disease.
Infectious protein, possibly self-replicating.
Inflammation of the rectum.
Inflammation of the colon (large intestine) and rectum.
An early symptom of a disease.
Describes substances such as cytokines that augment the initiation or amplification of the inflammatory response.
A stage in the life cycle of the protozoans in the genus Leishmania; a characteristic finding in host macrophages during infection.
Pertaining to agents or procedures that prevent disease processes in susceptible individuals; for example, giving vaccines or antibiotics to prevent an infection before it occurs.
Pertaining to a human-made replacement for a missing or defective body part, such as artificial limbs or heart valves.
An enzyme that catalyzes the degradation of a protein.
Intermediate stage of the Echinococcus life cycle; evaginate from daughter cysts upon infection of definitive host, attach to the intestinal wall, and develop to mature adults.
A phylum or subkingdom of the animal kingdom; contains many medically important unicellular parasites.
The part of a digit (finger or toe) that is closest to its attachment to the body.
Itching.
A false perception of increase in disease incidence, due to a contaminant or error in the testing process or a change in testing patterns.
Elongated yeast cells resembling hyphae, but which remain connected and unicellular.

Inflammation of the mucous membranes of the small and large intestines with the formation of false membranes composed of bacteria, white blood cells, fibrin, platelets, and necrotic material; occurs most frequently as a result of the action of exotoxins made by Clostridium difficile.
Drooping of the upper eyelid.
A technique that uses light to rapidly estimate the percentage of hemoglobin in the arterial blood, which is saturated with oxygen.
A cylindrical core of tissue obtained for histologic analysis.
Plugs placed to occlude the nasolacrimal duct.
Pertaining to lesions or markings that look like points or dots.
Purplish lesions of the skin and mucous membranes due to hemorrhage beneath the tissues; usually less than 1 cm in size, lesions may be flat or raised.
Related to presence, consistency, or formation of pus.
Pertaining to a skin rash with pus in the lesions.
Infection of the kidney with or without a concurrent bladder infection.
An infection of the skin that produces pus; caused by pyogenic bacteria.
Causing fever.
The presence of pus in the urine.
Weakness of all four extremities.
Coordinated gene expression in bacteria triggered by the release and detection of chemical signals; used in the formation of biofilms, virulence, and antibiotic resistance.
Abnormal breathing sounds (crackles) heard by auscultation of the lungs during respiration; classified as dry or moist.
A type of research study that randomly assigns patients to either an investigational therapy or no therapy (or placebo).
The process by which a latent infection can become active after a variable period of dormancy.
Mixing of genetic material into new combinations.
Pain that is worse upon release of the abdominal wall than upon compression of the abdominal wall, a sign of peritonitis.
Containing genetic material from more than one organism.
Inflammation of both the rectum and the colon.
Restoration of body fluids to normal osmolarity by adding fluids.
Pertaining to the kidney.
Diseases of significant public health importance that prompt registry of the case with the health department upon diagnosis.

The host, in nature, of an infectious agent. Some of these infectious agents may cause disease in humans after transmission from the reservoir either directly (e. g., a rabid bat bites a person) or indirectly (e. g., a rodent infected with Leptospira urinates in water in which a person later bathes).
A decrease in serum pH due to increased minute ventilation, decreased carbon dioxide, and decreased free hydrogen ions.
The anatomical structures involved in respiration, from the mouth, nose, and paranasal sinuses to the alveoli.
An immature red blood cell.
The specialized white blood cells (especially macrophages) and other cells in the lymph nodes, liver, and spleen.
Description of radiographic findings of interstitial lung disease, characterized by “ground glass” appearing opacities.
Referring to the retina.
Inflammation of the light-detecting tissue (retina) in the back of the eye.
A collection of pus posterior to the pharynx.
The synthesis of DNA from a single-stranded RNA template.

An illness that occurs in children with influenza or varicella; can result in encephalitis, liver involvement, coma, and death; strongly associated with the use of aspirin during the initial viral infection.
The first and second larval stages of the intestinal nematodes; this form is feeding and noninfectious.

An autoimmune disease of children and young adults that follows infection by group A streptococci; most severe sequelae are the destruction of heart tissue and scarring of heart valves, both of which can lead to heart failure.
A systemic, inflammatory, autoimmune disease with manifestations commonly in the joints, but also in the skin, eyes, lungs, kidneys, and cardiovascular system.
Inflammatory or infectious process involving the mucous membranes lining the nose.
Describes a disease that spreads from the mouth, nose, and sinuses to the brain.
Thin, watery discharge from the nose; runny nose.
Coarse, low-pitched sounds associated with the presence of secretions or obstruction of larger airways in the lungs during inspiration and expiration.
DNA template from which ribosomal RNA (rRNA) is made.
Genetic material within a ribosome, essential for protein synthesis.
Trophozoite form of malaria parasite.
Episodes of rigidity and shaking chills that may be brought on by infections; rigors may precede a fever.

Lesions in the brain seen on computed tomography (CT) scans, consisting of lucent (less dense to X rays), rounded masses surrounded by a region of increased density (especially with the use of vascular contrast material); often seen in certain infections of the brain.

Ribonucleic acid; a polymer of nucleotides that is produced from a DNA template; has several functions in protein synthesis, including directing the sequence of amino acids and serving as a constituent of the ribosome complex.
Inflammation or infection of a tube, usually the fallopian tubes between the ovaries and the uterus.

An illness caused by infection with group A streptococci; most prominent feature is the formation of numerous bright red spots on the skin and mucous membranes that are subsequently shed; before antibiotics, eruptions led to severe sequelae such as sepsis.
Yellow discoloration of the sclera due to elevated concentrations of bilirubin.

Recurrent or persistent obstructive jaundice due to extensive, destructive fibrosis of the bile ducts; frequently progresses to cirrhosis, liver failure, or portal hypertension; most common in young men.
An inexpensive, rapid test used for asymptomatic persons for a specific condition or trait; the test should be sensitive in order to avoid false negatives; usually followed by a confirmatory test.
Holocrine glands that excrete an oily substance called sebum, generally found in hair-covered areas.
An increase in the total number or volume of stools due to increased secretion or decreased reabsorption of electrolytes, caused by cholera toxin or enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli, for example.
Type of medium that inhibits the growth of some organisms while allowing the growth of others; useful when trying to isolate or detect specific organisms.

External factors that favor the growth of certain strains of microorganisms, thereby favoring particular genes such as those that encode virulence factors or antimicrobial resistance and resulting in such strains becoming more frequent in particular locations such as patients or hospital environments.
The ability of a diagnostic test to detect an organism if the organism is present; a very sensitive test should miss only a small number of infections; often a characteristic of screening tests.
The presence of the systemic inflammatory response syndrome as a result of an infection.
Having septa; divided into compartments; usually a description of hyphae in fungi.
Infection of the mother after the abortion of a fetus; can involve the uterus and become a widespread systemic infection.
Clot (blood or other occlusive material) carried by the blood that contains infectious agents; often leads to systemic infection; its occurrence can be sudden.

Hypotension as a result of sepsis, despite adequate fluid resuscitation, along with the presence of perfusion abnormalities of vital organs. This is a life-threatening condition that results in the increased permeability of the blood vessels, leading to excess fluid escaping into the tissues, abnormalities in cardiac function, and changes in vascular tone.
A condition that occurs as a result of a disease process.

The study of a patient's blood to determine the presence of specific antibodies to viruses or other microbes; can be used to determine exposure to a pathogen, to follow the course of a current infection by measuring the antibody level present, or to determine vaccination status.
Detection of the presence in the serum of antibodies to a particular antigen.
Differentiating different species or strains of a particular bacterium, fungus, or virus.
An immune complex disease that occurs approximately 1 to 2 weeks after a drug, foreign serum, or protein has been introduced into the body; local or systemic reactions can occur.
Iron-chelating compounds excreted by some microorganisms.
A disease characterized by lung inflammation and fibrosis caused by the immune response of alveolar macrophages to silica particles.
Pertaining to the lungs and paranasal sinuses.
Inflammation of the sinus cavities, often leading to headaches or nasal congestion.
