Transplant of a living- or deceased-donor organ (most commonly kidney or liver) into a patient.
Drowsy.
A laboratory measurement that allows for comparison of the density of a liquid with that of distilled water; frequently used to determine the relative concentration or dilution of urine.

The ability of a diagnostic test to detect the absence of an organism if the organism is absent; a positive test result with a very specific test should “rule in” disease; often a characteristic of confirmatory tests.
Removal of the spleen.
Of or pertaining to the spleen.
Enlargement of the spleen.
Inflammation or infection of the vertebra.
Pertaining to a spongelike appearance; when noted in brain tissue, it is indicative of the presence of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease or another prion disease.
The product of sexual or asexual reproduction in fungi; a very hardy latent form that certain bacteria can employ in the presence of environmental stress.
Urine that shows high numbers of white blood cells but no growth on culture.
The birth of a fetus that is dead before delivery.
Misalignment of the eyes, caused by discrepancies of the ocular muscles.
Type of breathing that is characterized by a high-pitched whistling sound; caused by obstruction of the upper airway.
A characteristic high-pitched cough associated with laryngeal blockage.
Being in a state of decreased consciousness that is characterized by a diminished sense of orientation and response to the environment.
Bleeding into the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater, usually resulting from a ruptured cerebral aneurysm or traumatic injury.
Refers to the area below the ridge that separates the right and left main bronchi at their junction with the trachea.
Describes a disease that does not show readily identifiable signs and symptoms.
Beneath the conjunctiva.
Inward movement of the area between the ribs, associated with an increased respiratory effort.
An antigen that induces a T-cell response by binding to a T-cell receptor in an area outside of the antigen recognition site; usually results in the activation of many T cells.
An enzyme found in white blood cells or some bacteria that catalyzes the dismutation of superoxide to hydrogen peroxide and oxygen.
An infection by organisms because of a previously acquired but ongoing infection (such as a bacterial pneumonia, which sometimes occurs during or after a viral pneumonia).
Refers to lying on the back with the face directed upward.
Of or relating to infection and inflammation.
Enlarged, tender lymph nodes from which pus is draining.
Systematic screening of hospitalized individuals for colonization or infection by an organism of epidemiologic significance at the institution.
Transient, brief episodic loss of consciousness (fainting).
A group of signs and symptoms that is characteristic of a particular disorder.
When the actions of two or more processes, structures, or agents are combined to yield a result that is greater than the sum of each individually; for example, antibiotics can be synergistic.
Inflammation of the joints.

A response to a stressor, especially infection, in which two or more of the following criteria are met: temperature >38°C or <36°C; heart rate >90 beats/min; respiratory rate >20 breaths/min or PaCO2 <32 mm Hg; and white blood cell count >12,000/mm 3 or <4,000/mm 3, or >10% immature (band) forms.
A sound that can be appreciated between S1 and S2 in the cardiac cycle.
Lymphocytes that mature in the thymus and are the primary components of cell-mediated immunity.
An MRI technique in which fat appears the brightest and water appears the darkest.
An MRI technique in which water appears the brightest and fat appears the darkest.

A neurologic disease of tertiary syphilis that results in destruction of the sensory or posterior portions of the spinal cord; when the upper spinal cord is involved, parts of the sympathetic nervous system can be involved.
Increased heart rate (>100 beats/min in adults).
Increase in respiratory rate (>20 breaths/min in adults).
An intermediate stage in the life cycle of Toxoplasma gondii; invades host cells of any tissue type and divides rapidly.

Type of flatworm of the class Cestoda; infects humans after the larva or eggs are ingested in contaminated food or water; some species may infect only the digestive tract, whereas others may disseminate to the brain, lungs, or liver.
Inflammation of the tough sheath surrounding a tendon.
Pertaining to agents that cause the abnormal development of an embryo, commonly resulting in fetal death or birth defects.
A decrease in the numbers of platelets.
Clotting within a blood vessel that may lead to infarction of the tissues supplied by that vessel.

An infection of the oral cavity that produces a white plaque; typically caused by the yeast Candida albicans in immunocompromised patients or in patients who have received broad-spectrum antibacterial agents.
The junction between two cells that is nearly impermeable to fluids.
A way to quantify the amount of antibody present through serial dilutions, expressed as a ratio of the dilution.
Receptor proteins on sentinel immune cells that recognize a broad range of pathogens and other proteins based on pattern recognition; a part of the innate immune system.
Of or pertaining to the tonsils.
Inflammation of one or more tonsils, usually the palatine tonsil.
Life-threatening acute inflammation and massive dilation of the colon, commonly associated with pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridioides difficile.
A poisonous substance that causes damage or death to cells.
A toxin that has been denatured into a nontoxic form; the toxin retains its antigenic potential and can be used in a vaccination.
Inflammation or infection of the trachea and bronchial tree.
Infection of the conjunctiva and cornea due to Chlamydia trachomatis; a major cause of blindness in the developing world.
During bronchoscopy, the removal of a small piece of lung tissue through the walls of a bronchus (airway).
The presence of bacteria in the bloodstream for a brief period of time followed by rapid clearance; patients with transient bacteremia are asymptomatic.
Applying a light to the skin overlying a body cavity to detect the presence of air.
The migration of bacteria from the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract to the mesenteric lymph nodes or blood.
A protein that spans through the entire lipid bilayer of a cell.
Crossing the placenta; pertaining to any substance that passes from the mother to the fetus or vice versa.
The valve through which blood flows from the right atrium to the right ventricle.
Spasm of the jaw muscles.
The pathogenic or non-cyst stage of certain protozoans.
Movement of an organism toward or away from a source of light, heat, or some other stimulus.
A tumor-like mass composed of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and the corresponding phagocytes that are unable to digest the bacteria.
A proinflammatory cytokine that causes fever, cachexia, and apoptosis.
The eardrum.
An incision made in the ear drum to allow drainage of fluid from the middle ear.
Pertaining to or resembling typhoid; disseminated infection without a particular anatomic focus.
Staining and microscopic examinations of the cells from a skin vesicle, used to identify cells infected with herpes simplex virus and varicella-zoster virus.
A lesion on the surface of the skin or mucous membranes caused by superficial loss of tissue; often accompanied by inflammation.
Describes disease resulting in ulcerations of the skin and regional lymphadenopathy.
Being composed of a single cell.
An enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of urea into carbon dioxide and ammonia.
Inflammation of the urethra.
A pathogen that infects the urinary tract.

Weakened (attenuated) or dead (inactivated) bacteria or virus, inactivated toxin (toxoid), or genetically engineered component of an infectious agent, used to promote immunity against a disease (such as smallpox or diphtheria).
Temperature-controlled storage and distribution of vaccines.
Inflammation of the vagina.
Inflammation of blood vessels leading to lesions on the skin, mucous membranes, or internal organs.
Relaxation of the smooth muscle surrounding blood vessels, resulting in an enlargement of the vessel lumen.
Endogenous or exogenous substances that promote vasoconstriction and improved oxygen delivery to tissues.
A clump of fibrin and platelets on the heart valves; may include microorganisms as a result of endocarditis or may be sterile.
A procedure used to draw blood or inject a solution that involves puncturing a vein.
Passage of an infectious agent from the mother to a fetus.
Pertaining to small, blisterlike lesions filled with clear fluid.
Pertaining to blisterlike lesions containing pus.
Violet or purple in color.
A quantitative measurement of the amount of virus present in the bloodstream; used as a means of following the course or severity of a viral infection.
The presence of viable virus in the bloodstream.
A trait of an infectious agent that gives the organism the capability to cause disease; may be a toxin, a biochemical component of the organism's outer surface, or other factor.
Refers to the particularly toxic effects of a pathogenic microorganism.

A particle composed of genetic material surrounded by a protein capsule; capable of infecting host cells by inserting the genetic material into the host cell and utilizing the host's machinery and energy to replicate.
Particles that contain the structure of a virus but lack viral genome and are therefore not infectious; used in vaccines and potentially in gene therapy.
The organs located within the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis.
A high-pitched whistling noise made when narrowed airway passages cause difficulty in breathing.
A wound dressing that applies negative pressure to an acute or chronic wound bed to promote wound healing.

Pertaining to diseases or conditions usually affecting vertebrates other than humans; however, humans can become infected after contact, either direct or indirect, with infected animals, their tissues, or their excrement.
Pertaining to a parasite or fungus with a preference for animals over humans.
An infection caused by fungi belonging to the zygomycetes; typically seen in either diabetics or immunocompromised hosts.
